title: Ryan Tandy
text:
Ryan Tandy (20 September 1981 – 28 April 2014) was an Australian professional <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> footballer who played in the 2000s and 2010s. An <a href="Ireland%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Ireland international</a> representative forward, he played in the <a href="National%20Rugby%20League">National Rugby League</a> for the <a href="St.%20George%20Illawarra%20Dragons">St. George Illawarra Dragons</a>, <a href="South%20Sydney%20Rabbitohs">South Sydney Rabbitohs</a>, <a href="Wests%20Tigers">Wests Tigers</a>, <a href="Melbourne%20Storm">Melbourne Storm</a>, and the <a href="Canterbury-Bankstown%20Bulldogs">Canterbury-Bankstown Bulldogs</a>, and in the <a href="Super%20League">Super League</a> for <a href="Hull%20Kingston%20Rovers">Hull Kingston Rovers</a>. He was banned from playing professional rugby league in Australia after being found guilty of <a href="spot-fixing">spot-fixing</a> during a match in 2010, and in 2014 died of a suspected drug overdose.
Background.
Of Irish heritage, Tandy was born in <a href="Gosford">Gosford</a>, <a href="New%20South%20Wales%2C%20Australia">New South Wales, Australia</a> on 20 September 1981. He played Junior <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> for the Kincumber Colts on the Central Coast of <a href="New%20South%20Wales">New South Wales</a>.
Playing career.
Tandy's career covered stints with the <a href="St.%20George%20Illawarra%20Dragons">St. George Illawarra Dragons</a>, <a href="South%20Sydney%20Rabbitohs">South Sydney Rabbitohs</a>, <a href="Wests%20Tigers">Wests Tigers</a>, <a href="Melbourne%20Storm">Melbourne Storm</a>, and the <a href="Canterbury-Bankstown%20Bulldogs">Canterbury-Bankstown Bulldogs</a> in the NRL. He also played for the <a href="Hull%20Kingston%20Rovers">Hull Kingston Rovers</a> in the <a href="Super%20League">Super League</a>. In the <a href="Rugby%20League%20Championships">National Leagues</a> system he played for <a href="Doncaster%20R.L.F.C.">Doncaster</a>, <a href="Widnes%20Vikings">Widnes Vikings</a>, <a href="Whitehaven%20R.L.F.C.">Whitehaven</a> and <a href="Barrow%20Raiders">Barrow</a>. He was an <a href="Ireland%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Ireland</a> international.
Tandy débuted for the <a href="Wests%20Tigers">Wests Tigers</a> first grade team against the Brisbane Broncos in Round 15 2008.
Tandy was selected in the <a href="Ireland%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Ireland</a> national team for the <a href="2008%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">2008 Rugby League World Cup</a>, which led to a contract with <a href="Melbourne%20Storm">Melbourne Storm</a> for 2009. He played for Melbourne in the <a href="2009%20NRL%20Grand%20Final">2009 NRL Grand Final</a> victory against <a href="Parramatta%20Eels">Parramatta</a>, but the premiership title was later stripped from the Storm due to salary cap breaches.
He signed with the <a href="Canterbury-Bankstown%20Bulldogs">Canterbury-Bankstown Bulldogs</a> on 12 June 2010, and was sacked by them on 18 March 2011.
Betting scandal.
After the 21 August 2010 Canterbury-Bankstown match against the <a href="North%20Queensland%20Cowboys">North Queensland Cowboys</a> Tandy became embroiled in a betting scandal. The <a href="Totalisator%20Agency%20Board">Totalisator Agency Board</a> (TAB) announced that 95 per cent of bets placed on the first scoring play of this match were for the unusual option of a Cowboys penalty goal. Friends and associates of Tandy placed a large number of bets, with the total windfall for a successful bet expected to be over $100,000. Tandy was then responsible for two actions in the match to allow the opposing side to score a penalty goal inside the first two minutes: first by giving away possession to the Cowboys in the opening moments of the match by knocking on, and then giving away a penalty in the play-the-ball ten metres in front of the goal posts. These actions put the Cowboys in a position where a penalty goal was a likely outcome; but they decided on an attacking option and scored a try instead.
Tandy denied the accusations of deliberately giving away possession and a penalty to allow the exotic option on the bets to be successful. Despite this, he was arrested on 2 February 2011 for providing false evidence to a law enforcement agency during the investigation of the betting scandal. Tandy was in more than $70,000 debt at the time of the match, owing to losses from his own long-standing gambling addiction.
On 6 October 2011, Tandy was found to be guilty of manipulating the first scoring point of the game. He received an intensive correction order for six months. It required: community service, supervision and curfew, but he could have been jailed for two years. He appealed the charge in January 2014 but lost the case. Tandy received a lifetime ban from NRL rugby league over the <a href="spot%20fixing">spot fixing</a>.
Later life and death.
In January 2014, Tandy was arrested and charged with kidnapping in connection with the recovery of a drug debt from the victim, police alleging that Tandy was serving as a standover man. Three months after being bailed, Tandy was found dead at his parents' home in <a href="Saratoga%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Saratoga, New South Wales</a>, following what is believed to have been an accidental overdose of prescription drugs.
